channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DATAMONGO-1471] MappingMongoConverter attempts to set null value on potentially primitive identifier
item.description:
An exception occurs when there is no _id in the query result(the id attribute is a primitive type, such as long). This also happens on _id of embedded object.

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Can not set long field Employee.id to null value
 
	at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.throwSetIllegalArgumentException(UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.java:167)
 
	at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.throwSetIllegalArgumentException(UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.java:171)
 
	at sun.reflect.UnsafeLongFieldAccessorImpl.set(UnsafeLongFieldAccessorImpl.java:80)
 
	at java.lang.reflect.Field.set(Field.java:764)
 
	at org.springframework.util.ReflectionUtils.setField(ReflectionUtils.java:122)
 
	at org.springframework.data.mapping.model.BeanWrapper.setProperty(BeanWrapper.java:59)
 
	at org.springframework.data.mapping.model.ConvertingPropertyAccessor.setProperty(ConvertingPropertyAccessor.java:58)
 
	at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.convert.MappingMongoConverter.read(MappingMongoConverter.java:265)
 
	at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.convert.MappingMongoConverter.read(MappingMongoConverter.java:232)
 
	at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.convert.MappingMongoConverter.readValue(MappingMongoConverter.java:1196)
 
	at org.springframework.data.mongodb.core.convert.MappingMongoConverter.access$200(MappingMongoConverter.java:79)
item.summary: MappingMongoConverter attempts to set null value on potentially primitive identifier

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
A simple not null judgement should fix this.

if(idValue != null){
 
    accessor.setProperty(idProperty, idValue);
 
}

Would you mind elaborating a bit on the class structure you're reading? Also, the complete stack trace would be helpful. It's not obvious what is calling the converter actually. We can't simply not invoke the setters for null as existing applications might rely on that behavior.

If the property is a primitive one as you're saying, how did your document actually ending up containing a null value in the first place? If you have another application manipulating those documents and they generally can write null values (instead of removing the field entirely) then I guess you just have to model your domain classes in a way that they can cope with that situation, e.g. by using non-primitive variants like Integer etc.

Oh, by the way, I just cloned your sample project and ran mvn clean test and those tests succeed.

Hi Oliver,

Thanks for looking at this. Those tests are intended to succeed, since the expected exception(see @Test(expected = IllegalArgumentException.class)) is thrown. In that two test cases, there is no _id in the query result because it is not included in the fields list.

In our real case, it's because we don't have an id attribute on the Department model before, so the legacy data don't have department._id, after we add id attribute, the query errors out.

I added a new test case for our real case which is caused by legacy data: https://github.com/xuyuanjin/playground/blob/master/spring-data-mongodb-test/src/test/java/TestLegacyData.java

Change the Department.id to a Long type will solve this, but it makes more sense to be solved by the framework.

> Change the Department.id to a Long type will solve this, but it makes more sense to be solved by the framework.

I disagree. Strongly. Here is why: The conversion subsystem is designed in a way that if you read a document from the store and write it back without changing the object instance, you'd end up with the very same document. The problem with your suggestion is that it would fundamentally break that design rule: you read a document with a null value, by not getting applied to the object instance, you'd end up with the primitive's type default in the object. Writing that back would write the default where previously null was in place.

Ok, that makes sense if we are reading the whole object. But what about the _id or nested _id field excluded scenarios? I think in that case the framework should process properly but not throw an exception.
If the field is excluded it does not appear in the document returned by MongoDB, and thus there's no null value to handle.
Ok, so you will fix it (when _id excluded), right?

Currently when _id is excluded MappingMongoConverter throws an IllegalArgumentException.

see test cases in:
https://github.com/xuyuanjin/playground/blob/master/spring-data-mongodb-test/src/test/java/TestIdExcluded.java
Good one! I've fixed that in master (Ingalls) and back-ported the fix to the maintenance branches for Hopper and Gosling. Feel free to give the snapshots a try.
I tested 1.9.3.BUILD-SNAPSHOT locally and it passed, thanks!
